content: Several tax options have been proposed to finance health care reform, including restricting itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers, modifying the tax exclusion for employer-provided health care, increasing taxes on alcoholic beverages, and imposing an excise tax on non-diet sweetened beverages. The House Ways and Means Committee proposed a surtax on high-income individuals, while the Senate Finance Committee reported a bill relying on an excise tax on insurers for high-cost plans. The House proposed a surtax on high-income individuals to finance health care reform, while the Senate relied on an excise tax on insurers for high-cost plans. President Obama's compromise proposal used H.R. 3590 as a starting point with changes to revenue provisions, including delaying the tax on high-cost employer plans to 2018 and raising exemption thresholds. The proposal also included a 3.8% tax on unearned income for high-income households. The House passed H.R. 3590 and H.R. 4872 on March 22, 2010, which was signed into law by the President. The burden of tax changes can vary based on income levels, with progressive changes affecting higher-income taxpayers more, proportional changes affecting all taxpayers equally, and regressive changes affecting lower-income taxpayers more. For example, limits on deductions and taxes on high incomes are highly progressive, while excise taxes tend to be regressive. Distributional analysis in this report focuses on financing mechanisms, not overall effects of health care reform proposals, which may benefit lower-income families. The report focuses on the financing mechanisms of health care reform proposals, highlighting the redistribution in favor of lower-income individuals despite regressive revenue sources. Key revenue raisers include increased Medicare tax, fees on health insurance providers, "Cadillac" tax on employer health insurance premiums, and fees on branded drugs. Various income tax provisions could potentially be used to generate additional revenues, including rate increases, widening rate brackets, expanding the base, or increasing tax rates on favored income items like dividends and capital gains. Suggestions include reducing indexing of rate brackets to CPI minus 1% instead of CPI, estimated to raise $8 billion in 2010 and $50 billion in 2019. Other proposals include increasing the capital gains tax, taxing carried interest as ordinary income, reforming international tax enforcement, and repealing LIFO inventories. Revenue estimates for these items are available in the Treasury's "Greenbook". Increasing revenue for a growing healthcare plan can be achieved through various measures such as raising tax rates on capital gains and dividends, taxing carried interest as ordinary income, reforming international tax enforcement, and repealing LIFO inventories. Estimates suggest that these actions could generate significant revenue, with international reforms alone raising over $20 billion. Additionally, increasing payroll taxes, eliminating the Social Security earnings cap, and adjusting the employee and employer share of payroll taxes could further contribute to revenue generation. Burman estimates that increasing payroll taxes for both employees and employers could raise $100 billion annually. Eliminating the Social Security earnings cap could generate $84 billion in revenue. Another proposal is a 10% value added tax (VAT) to raise $600 billion, but it comes with administrative challenges. Alternative revenue sources include a carbon tax or auction revenue from a cap and trade system, each with their own implementation difficulties and program issues. Implementing a carbon tax or cap and trade system for revenue generation poses challenges and would require resolving various program issues. The administration and compliance costs, along with transition problems, make these options difficult to put into place quickly. Additionally, these taxes would be regressive.
